row.entry: This Rule imposes a general requirement for parties to file originating process, or an appearance, before taking any step in proceedings.

This Division provides for two forms of originating process: statement of claim or summons. It describes the circumstances in which each form is required and permits remedial directions where the inappropriate form has been used.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Defendant to proceedings to enter appearance — Rules 6.9–6.11

row.entry: This Division (read with rÂ 14.3 ) requires defendants to file a defence or notice of appearance, within 28 days.

entry.emph: Division 4 — Contents of statement of claim and summons — Rules 6.12–6.17

row.entry: These rules define some of the formal contents of originating process including a statement of the relief claimed, the return date of any summons and various notices required to be given to defendants.

entry.emph: Division 5 — Joinder of causes of action and joinder of parties — Rules 6.18–6.28

row.entry: This Division describes the circumstances in which multiple causes of action and parties can be included in the same proceedings.
This Division allows the court to remove unnecessary parties from proceedings. It contains specific rules governing the conduct of proceedings after the death or bankruptcy of a party.

entry.emph: Division 7 — Orders as to future conduct of proceedings — Rule 6.32

row.entry: This Rule allows the court to give directions about the conduct of proceedings where orders are made in relation to the joinder of parties or causes of action.

entry.emph: Division 8 — Referred questions of law and stated cases — Rules 6.33–6.41

row.entry: These rules prescribe the form and contents of originating process in proceedings where questions of law, or stated cases, are referred to the Supreme Court.

entry.emph: Division 9 — Issues arising under foreign law — Rules 6.42–6.45

row.entry: These rules set out the requirements for commencing and continuing proceedings where an issue arises in relation to a law of a foreign country.

Divisions 1, 3 and 5–7 of this Part apply to all courts in CPA Sch 1 except as set out below. Divisions 2 and 4 apply to all courts other than in relation to class 1, 2 or 3 proceedings in the Land and Environment Court. Divisions 8 and 9 apply only to proceedings in the Supreme Court. Part 6 does not apply to the Industrial Court or the Industrial Relations Commission.

The rules are based substantially on the former SCR PartsÂ 4, 5, 7, 8 and 11; DCR PartÂ 7; and LCR PartÂ 6. The rules relating to the choice of originating process are slightly more prescriptive than the previous rules. The rules relating to joinder are substantially the same as the previous Supreme Court Rules. The rules relating to stated cases and referred questions of law are based on the previous SCR PtÂ 32 rÂ 7 and FCR O 50.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.1] r 6.1 No step without originating process or notice of appearance (cf SCR Part 11, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: No step without originating process or notice of appearance (cf SCR Part 11, rule 2)

p.text: Except by leave of the court, a party may not take any step in proceedings, including any appearance in court, unless the party has filed a statement of claim or summons in the proceedings or has entered an appearance in the proceedings.
[subr (1) am Amendment 7 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 10 March 2006]
Subrule (1) does not apply to:
a defendant who applies for an order under rule 12.11 (Setting aside originating process etc), or
a plaintiff who applies for an order under rule 25.2 (Order in urgent case before commencement of proceedings), or
a defendant who makes an application in relation to the setting aside or enforcement of any judgment.
[subr (2) subst ; Amendment 7 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[2],effective 10 March 2006]

In any proceedings, a person (not being a party and not having filed a notice of motion) may not take any step in the proceedings (including any appearance in court) unless he or she has filed a notice of address for service.
[subr (3) subst ; Amendment 7 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 10 March 2006]
The approved forms are:
Statement of Claim: Form 3A (where the filing party is legally represented) and Form 3B (where the filing party is acting in person or by authorised officer).
Summons: Form 4A (where the filing party is legally represented) and Form 4B (where the filing party is acting in person or by authorised officer).
Notice of Appearance: Form 6 .
Legislation cited in [6.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 14.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.2.

The “except by leave” qualification to which the rule is subject obviously contemplates that leave applications may be made before filing either initiating process or an appearance. And, despite the absence of any express qualification in subrule 6.1(3), the present rule does not prevent the court from exercising its general power to dispense with the requirements of the rules in appropriate cases: see under CPA s 14 . Appropriate circumstances to justify the exercise of either discretion will exist if the contemplated “step” in the proceedings involves either urgency or pedestrian formality, and the desirable regularity of procedure intended by the rule can otherwise be appropriately obtained. Consistent with that generality, it is relatively common for the court, particularly in urgent cases, to accept an undertaking to file an appearance within a limited time and, upon such an undertaking, grant leave to a defendant to take steps in the proceedings. Sub-rule 6.1(2) expressly excludes the present rule from applying to applications to set aside either originating process or judgments, or to applications for urgent relief under UCPR r 25.2 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.1A] r 6.1A Proceedings that do not require a defendant (cf SCR Part 58, rule 1, Part 70, rule 11, Part 73, rule 4 and Schedule J)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings that do not require a defendant (cf SCR Part 58, rule 1, Part 70, rule 11, Part 73, rule 4 and Schedule J)

p.text: Unless the court otherwise orders, proceedings that may be commenced without joining any person as a defendant include the following:
proceedings under the Adoption Act 2000,
proceedings under section 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995,
proceedings under the Jury Act 1977,
proceedings under section 17 of the Witness Protection Act 1995,
proceedings under rule 55.9.
[r 6.1A insrt Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 5 October 2007]
Legislation cited in [6.1A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 52.1, UCPR r 55.9, UCPR r 56.2.
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995 s 33.
(NSW) Trustee Act 1925.
(NSW) Adoption Act 2000.

Other provisions of the rules may apply to proceedings to which the present rule applies: see also UCPR r 52.1 for procedure under Evidence on Commission Act 1995 s 33 ; UCPR r 55.9 for cases where proceedings are required for payment into court under the Trustee Act 1925 ; UCPR r 56.2 for commencement of proceedings under the Adoption Act 2000 .

The present rule is inclusive. Other proceedings may be permissible even though they do not name an identified entity as a defendant to the proceedings: International Finance Trust Co Ltd v NSW Crime Commission (2008) 251 ALR 479; 232 FLR 37; [2008] NSWCA 291; BC200809816 at [143]Â (proceedings under the Criminal Assets Recovery Act 1900 (NSW) — the proceedings had a statutory “in rem” effect against the property concerned and were properly brought).
